componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Carlo Santarelli of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've long been a proponent of having a capital structure that match the operating environment. So I don't think this necessarily would come as a total surprise, but as you contemplated the dividend, and you thought about some of the CapEx expenditures t
componenttext: You've long been a proponent of having a capital structure that match the operating environment. So I don't think this necessarily would come as a total surprise, but as you contemplated the dividend, and you thought about some of the CapEx expenditures that were coming over the next 2 years, what kind of drove you to make this decision today? And does it say anything about your view on the outlook for Macau over the next 18 to 24 months other than just what we've already seen and that it remains very murky?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Carlo, it's Matt Maddox. When we were reviewing this Steve put it perfectly that we don't plan on giving up our own money. So if you look at our payout ratio based on our adjusted earnings per share, what we're looking at right now is similar to what we d
componenttext: Carlo, it's Matt Maddox. When we were reviewing this Steve put it perfectly that we don't plan on giving up our own money. So if you look at our payout ratio based on our adjusted earnings per share, what we're looking at right now is similar to what we did last year. So that's really the way we're looking at the capital structure, and there's so much uncertainty right now in Las Vegas and Macau and with our project coming on next year that we're just not going to give dividend with borrowed money.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood, Matt. And just one follow-up on Macau, guys. Was there any differential or any meaningful differential between your direct and VIP on the hold side or what we're seeing maybe a little bit on the cost creep from some of the fixed expenses in th
componenttext: Understood, Matt. And just one follow-up on Macau, guys. Was there any differential or any meaningful differential between your direct and VIP on the hold side or what we're seeing maybe a little bit on the cost creep from some of the fixed expenses in the business?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say there was really no impact from a hold standpoint on margins, and clearly, there is a little bit of cost creep. If you look at the fourth quarter of '14 to the first quarter this year, you can see that, and operating expenses today are up arou
componenttext: I would say there was really no impact from a hold standpoint on margins, and clearly, there is a little bit of cost creep. If you look at the fourth quarter of '14 to the first quarter this year, you can see that, and operating expenses today are up around 7%.

componenttext: Our new junket rooms did well, but the other junket operators that were quite as powerful, I wouldn't say they scavenge the other ones, but the new junket rooms are in the hands of very well-financed operators. So the rooms were very well received, and they've been lively, and they've been busy.

componenttext: So 2 questions on occupancy. So in Macau, your occupancy held in relatively well. Some of your peers you saw sizable drops. And then just second part of the question is just on Vegas, we saw a decline in occupancy. Was that a function of just the con ad comp or something else?

componenttextpreview: We have a slightly different eco climate on The Peninsula. We also have a smaller inventory of rooms than the big operators in side. So with 1,000 keys, we also had a shift of rooms into our premium mass and mass segments. So we have some new reward progr
componenttext: We have a slightly different eco climate on The Peninsula. We also have a smaller inventory of rooms than the big operators in side. So with 1,000 keys, we also had a shift of rooms into our premium mass and mass segments. So we have some new reward programs where we're getting approximately 100 rooms a day more to our premium mass and mass areas, where we've been able to grow a midsection of our mass business very nicely despite the downturn of business. So we've utilized the inventory where the business is. So we've kept our occupancy virtually the same as last year.

componenttext: So where you have a lot of business that really was interested at being in Las Vegas during that month as is opposed to the previous year where we are spread out throughout February and March as well. componenttextpreview: Well, for April and May, we have a strong base and stable base of convention as well as leisure mix. Summer's going to be interesting. We're starting to see summer trends not pick up the same way they did in previous year. So we're paying very close atten
componenttext: Well, for April and May, we have a strong base and stable base of convention as well as leisure mix. Summer's going to be interesting. We're starting to see summer trends not pick up the same way they did in previous year. So we're paying very close attention to the market and what we're getting is indicators as far as the summer business, but it does seem as strong at this point as it was last year.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you were to ask me since we're making forward-looking statements, what will the second quarter look like in Las Vegas? Weak. Do you hear me? Weak. So I'm trying to lower expectations here. This notion of a big recovery is a complete dream. I don't thin
componenttext: If you were to ask me since we're making forward-looking statements, what will the second quarter look like in Las Vegas? Weak. Do you hear me? Weak. So I'm trying to lower expectations here. This notion of a big recovery is a complete dream. I don't think Las Vegas is experiencing a great recovery. I think it's still very patchy, and I think that that's probably our non-casino revenue in the first quarter was flat. I'd be thrilled if it was flat in the second quarter. Would you, Maurice?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would be.
componenttext: I would be.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Did you hear that? There's 2 of us saying we'd be thrilled if non-casino revenue was flat on the second quarter as it was in the first. My guess is that that's going to be a struggle.
componenttext: Did you hear that? There's 2 of us saying we'd be thrilled if non-casino revenue was flat on the second quarter as it was in the first. My guess is that that's going to be a struggle.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what do you think is driving it? I mean, as you think about this summer, is that the strengthening U.S. dollar? Is it something else? And then just I'm going to sneak in one more question just when you talked about Cotai Palace opening up, hoping to op
componenttext: So what do you think is driving it? I mean, as you think about this summer, is that the strengthening U.S. dollar? Is it something else? And then just I'm going to sneak in one more question just when you talked about Cotai Palace opening up, hoping to open up in March of next year, can you just give us an update on just the labor allocation? I think there was a mention about that last quarter. I'm done.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, on our labor allocation, we got less than we asked for than we appealed, and they gave us a more then we made another application, and they gave us less than we asked for, and we appealed that. I'm not sure how exactly the process works in the calcu
componenttext: Well, on our labor allocation, we got less than we asked for than we appealed, and they gave us a more then we made another application, and they gave us less than we asked for, and we appealed that. I'm not sure how exactly the process works in the calculations that are done at the Labor Department in Macau. These jobs have, after all, are people from Mainland China just on the other side of the fence. But there's pressure locally. I guess it's sort of the locals don't want the streets too crowded or something, and they put pressure on the local government officials, and they respond. They're very sensitive to local pressure. So it leaves us in a bit of a quandary. We never know quite what to expect these days, and uncertainty for our employees we're beginning to notice that -- we have the lowest -- let me start over on this. In that town where, there's a 25% to 30% turnover rate, our company stands alone with a current rate of 8%. All of last year was 11%. All our employees are very sticky. They like us. They stay with us. That's a big advantage when you're building a new property. However, every one of our employees in Macau is a shareholder of Wynn Macau, and they're counting on the accumulated dividends, the value of those shares as their basic savings. The current situation in Macau is threatening them. And unfortunately, I'm not in a position to protect them from the exposures to the changes that have been brought about in the marketplace. We try and deal with that as we build the new place, but there's no question that uncertainty is the plaguing word of the day in Macau. And hopefully, our government in Macau will calm that down and put some certainty back into the picture, and that'll be very important to the employees, who are basically Macau citizens. But they're beginning to feel these rumbles, and I fear that, that may erupt into protests against the government if it isn't settled soon.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And sorry just following up from my first question. What do you think is driving the weakness during the summer in Las Vegas? Is it the stronger U.S. dollar? Is it fewer play out of China? And then again I'm done after that.
componenttext: And sorry just following up from my first question. What do you think is driving the weakness during the summer in Las Vegas? Is it the stronger U.S. dollar? Is it fewer play out of China? And then again I'm done after that.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Both of the 2 things that you just mentioned are in play. And secondly or thirdly, the recovery in America is a jobless recovery in real terms and inflation in America in real terms is an enormous number. So I think that the general economic recovery in t
componenttext: Both of the 2 things that you just mentioned are in play. And secondly or thirdly, the recovery in America is a jobless recovery in real terms and inflation in America in real terms is an enormous number. So I think that the general economic recovery in the United States has been grossly overstated, and we're an echo of that here in Las Vegas as one of America's main destination resort cities. And all of you get to hear these kinds of comments from other public companies that are engaged in this business, and I think the pictures are beginning to emerge.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Greff of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Greff of JPMorgan.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe a difficult question to answer, Steve. I think you touched on it in a couple of the answers here, but do you think the Macau government cares if the new projects that are opening in Cotai over the next few years if those new projects cannibalize the
componenttext: Maybe a difficult question to answer, Steve. I think you touched on it in a couple of the answers here, but do you think the Macau government cares if the new projects that are opening in Cotai over the next few years if those new projects cannibalize the existing base of casino hotels, particularly if that generates disruptions to social harmony locally in Macau. How do those topics of conversation, how do they go when you potentially bring that up as a topic of conversation with the government there?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: What a great question, and first of all, it will impact social harmony, but the government officials are balancing, I think at this point, a lot of issues that have emanated from Beijing and also emanates from their own population. How they walk that tigh
componenttext: What a great question, and first of all, it will impact social harmony, but the government officials are balancing, I think at this point, a lot of issues that have emanated from Beijing and also emanates from their own population. How they walk that tight rope and what their decisions are, are at the moment, unpredictable to us because we can't sit in there -- we can't stand in their shoes. We don't really know how much pressure they feel the different areas. We hear their public statements, and we certainly enjoy private conversations with them, but they tend to be very formal. They're never critical of anything directly. When they want something, they make requests. It's a very civilized process, but there's no question that the atmosphere there has changed and become cloudier in terms of predictability and consistency. It's definitely become cloudy. They had a press conference, one of the new ministers as part of this government made a statement in front of legislature that the light-rail system, which has been under development for 5 years that I'm aware of or 6 years, that they don't have any idea exactly when that'll be finished or what it's going to cost. I'm sure that was a painful thing for the man to say exact words. You cannot excuse the excusable. I'm here just to apologize. Well, if that's going on at the highest levels of the government in Macau, and you can imagine how what it happened since it filters down to those of us who are part of the resort industry. So I don't know if I'm being very helpful in passing on my impressions, but I'm doing the best I can.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, and then I have a quick question following up on your rather crystal-clear comments on the Las Vegas Strip. If you were to look at the non-Chinese resort Baccarat player, is that segment in Las Vegas Strip relatively healthier or in good shape?
componenttext: Great, and then I have a quick question following up on your rather crystal-clear comments on the Las Vegas Strip. If you were to look at the non-Chinese resort Baccarat player, is that segment in Las Vegas Strip relatively healthier or in good shape?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say it's not necessarily healthier. I would again look at the same just that we have with respect to Far East market, I think that they are paying close attention to traveling over here and whether they should or whether they shouldn't. So if that
componenttext: I would say it's not necessarily healthier. I would again look at the same just that we have with respect to Far East market, I think that they are paying close attention to traveling over here and whether they should or whether they shouldn't. So if that's measurable, it's a little different than when you're high in play.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're going to have -- we're having this call today on the eve of the upcoming Pacquiao fight and Mayweather fight, and this in my 40-odd years in this town, this is a one-off. I have never seen madness and demand of this sort. This fight is probably goi
componenttext: You're going to have -- we're having this call today on the eve of the upcoming Pacquiao fight and Mayweather fight, and this in my 40-odd years in this town, this is a one-off. I have never seen madness and demand of this sort. This fight is probably going to break all records for pay-per-view. It's certainly breaking all records in what they're getting for tickets. We've never charged more than $1,500 for a ringside seat in a fight, and they're going for $10,000 and then $7,500 for the medium range and then $5,000 for the ones in the upper tier, an outrageous amount of money. Mayweather and Pacquiao are going to not only have to have a fight, but they're probably going to have to do a chorus line or something to justify the cost of this. But our room rates are at $1,300, $1,400, $1,500 for typical rooms, and you can't get a room in this town. I've never seen anything like it even when fought Leonard, Ali, nothing like this, and there's a lot of Baccarat business coming to town this weekend, a ton of them. So we're going to have one of these New Year's Eve, Chinese New Year post, but I'm try to give an overview here of what's really going on in terms of the tempo of the city here, and I think we ought to keep our eye on the ball on the long view as opposed to the short view.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shaun Kelley of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shaun Kelley of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back to the dividend philosophy for a quick second. Matt, you mentioned I think in response to another question the idea basically of payout ratio as it relates to your current earnings per share. And I was wondering is that something that
componenttext: Just to circle back to the dividend philosophy for a quick second. Matt, you mentioned I think in response to another question the idea basically of payout ratio as it relates to your current earnings per share. And I was wondering is that something that we should look to as sort of a guidepost for this? And how often should we think that the dividend will be reevaluated? Is this a quarterly thing? Or is it going to be a kind of this is what you think you need to get through Cotai from here?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to answer it, Steve. It is quarterly reviewed. We said $0.50 a share because we thought that was a relatively stable number, a couple of hundred million dollars. If we do $1 billion in EBITDA or something like that, we probably have $400 m
componenttext: Well, I'm going to answer it, Steve. It is quarterly reviewed. We said $0.50 a share because we thought that was a relatively stable number, a couple of hundred million dollars. If we do $1 billion in EBITDA or something like that, we probably have $400 million in free cash flow right now.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We could safely say half of that. We could have said $3 instead of $2 a year, but I decided that until we get a clearer picture of this, I was going to try to avoid another reduction if I could. But I want to make it clear, Mr. Kelly. I wouldn't think twi
componenttext: We could safely say half of that. We could have said $3 instead of $2 a year, but I decided that until we get a clearer picture of this, I was going to try to avoid another reduction if I could. But I want to make it clear, Mr. Kelly. I wouldn't think twice if there was another big change in changing it every quarter, up or down. Make no mistake about it. We do not feel it is an appropriate, prudent management to make promises about distribution in a business that fluctuates. Now that may be bad news to some investors, who would prefer to know that it just comes off like a clockwork. But this is not that kind of the company, and it's never really going to be that kind of the company. We'll get bigger. I think we'll do fine with Cotai as a percentage of return on its investment. I think we'll do great in Boston as a percentage of return on its investment. And therefore, the company will, grow and the available cash flow will increase hopefully, and so will our dividend because we're a distribution company. But at the moment, I mean, one of the benefits of the fact that we are a distribution company is that we distributed billions of dollars to our shareholders. That's good news, but it's not an inherent promise of the fixed amount of money. It's only an inherent promise of our approach to the problem. Hear me on this. There'll be no change in that attitude while I'm sitting in my chair.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. I think that's crystal clear. And then I guess second question, and this is certainly changing topics a little bit was I noticed in the release that when you look at the mix in the mass business and what you saw during the quarter, I looked at the
componenttext: Got it. I think that's crystal clear. And then I guess second question, and this is certainly changing topics a little bit was I noticed in the release that when you look at the mix in the mass business and what you saw during the quarter, I looked at the whole ratio, it was up. It's always been hard to read those numbers, particularly in recent times, but my question is did you guys see it more of a shift to premium mass in the quarter? Or was it pretty balanced than what you saw in sort of the more grind mass and the higher end part of mass just kind of curious to what you guys saw throughout the quarter.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Linda or Frank in Macau, I know it's late or early. You want to tick up on that?

componenttext: Actually just to be clear, it was my counterpart in Hong Kong who did it, not me. So we'll a short way come up. So just I guess a question. Given so much uncertainty in Macau and Vegas, why not scale back the project or delay the project in Boston? Why not do the same thing in Macau? Why -- maybe need to slow that down.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hold on. You can't slow it down. It's been finished, and there's bank obligations. You can't slow it down in Macau. The building is sitting there. The skin is on. They're getting ready to fill the lake. Staff is hired. I don't suspect that we're going to
componenttext: Hold on. You can't slow it down. It's been finished, and there's bank obligations. You can't slow it down in Macau. The building is sitting there. The skin is on. They're getting ready to fill the lake. Staff is hired. I don't suspect that we're going to lose money in Macau if that's your -- if you're difference. I don't -- I'm not applying -- I don't want you to prefer that. Boston, we have made hard and fast commitments to the Gaming Commission in Massachusetts. These things are really -- you're very much handcuffed and what you say and what you require to do in these conditions when you go before these regulatory agencies such as Massachusetts. You don't get much wiggle room. You can certainly make sure you have complete drawings and hard and fast numbers on the cost of the project even if it takes an extra few months to get the drawings down, and we surely will do that.

componenttext: So why don't you lay that out for people because I think there's going to be a lot of anxiety tomorrow that a guy like you, who's been around for a while, and who's pretty thoughtful is cutting his dividend and is talking about how terrible things are yet is also spending quite a bit of money because you truly believe in the long-term market in Macau and in Massachusetts. So why don't you lay out why if that's the case.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. First of all, my comments on the dividend are irrelevant to the moment. They just explain how we approach distributions, and I think that applies in good times and hard times as well. In terms of my long-term view, what I object to very often is thi
componenttext: Okay. First of all, my comments on the dividend are irrelevant to the moment. They just explain how we approach distributions, and I think that applies in good times and hard times as well. In terms of my long-term view, what I object to very often is this unrelenting attempt to CEOs and their agencies in these calls to try and support the stock price with rosy predictions that do not come true. What I'm interested in accomplishing when we have these phone calls is to build up a structure of trustworthiness and suitability about the way we run the company. In order to do that, I have to be very candid about what we see and the conditions that we find ourselves in, and I don't know any other way to handle this and still be true to the notion of creating consistency in the way people perceive the management's common sense and my Board of Director's comments. Incidentally, all of us are totally unanimous on this approach. If I start to talk about gee, don't worry about all this. The long-term is going to be great. Although my instincts tell me that, that has to be true, I mean, after all, President Gin Ping, he instituted this campaign against corruption based upon his explicit explanation that he felt that there was a perception in the 1,300,000,000 Chinese that government officials were corrupt. Of course, there were members of the Communist Party, and that this corruption undermined the public's faith in its government. And therefore, he was bound and determined to change that period, and he set out on this campaign. And if we were to believe the South China Morning Post, a leading newspaper of South China and Hong Kong, then thousands upon thousands of public officials have been brought up on accusations of misconduct of varying degrees. And it's starting at the bureau itself, which is unprecedented and descending all the way down the chain of command to local governments. If this observation is accurate, then Gin Ping is doing the right thing for the right reason. Now does that create a new norm? I don't know. People like to use phrases like that, the new norm. Newspaper people love to be able to make far-reaching and categorical statements. They're irresponsible when they do that. There are no far-reaching and categorical statements, but we know this the only reason the President did this was to strengthen public confidence in his government. His speeches in Macau at December was unequivocal. He supports the continuing prosperity and diversification like our new resort of the offerings for tourism and other industries in Macau. He was unequivocal in that statement, and he has begun to take steps in Mainland China to privatize and to make the government-owned companies even more responsive to the public or to change them to private. If the Communist Party and its leadership are dedicated to a peaceful, growing and harmonious China, then it's hard to believe that they would do anything to sabotage one of their key positions, Macau, going forward or Hong Kong for that matter. And for that reason, one can be very positive about the long-term future of China and its special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. I look at that big picture to draw my confidence in our participation and hopefully, our long-term participation there as agents of development and change, as visitors and guests of that country to bring about positive results. So there's my long-term view and the reason for it. But these short-term implications are significant. We've lost half the province. You go from making $4 million a day to $2 million a day. Now considering that the success we've had in Macau, $2 million a day would be terrific anywhere else. But compared to the unbelievable events of the past few years, it seems morbid. It's not morbid. Am I being responsive to you in explaining why I tend to talk about what we see and what we think, and I'm trying to deal with the next 6 or 8 months, and it's hard to do. I've been doing this for 40-odd years I have to tell you, and I talked to Sheldon. We're very good friends. It's hard for us. It's hard for Rob Goldstein and the rest of the people, our neighbors next door were up to their eyebrows in development investments in China. They've noticed it in Singapore as well, and then we hear that finally, it appears the Japanese are going to pass -- are on the threshold of passing a study build. We've always been told that if they weren't going to do it, they wouldn't have a study build in the diet. But now it turns out there's going to be a study build it appears this week. We spent the -- I spent the day yesterday with a deputation from Osaka, the whole day yesterday with Osaka, and they were here touring all the hotels. So there's a lot of good news, and I love our opportunity in Boston, and we're going to build them the first really grand hotel in the city with nonstop service from every major capital in Europe, Latin America, Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai. So I don't want to stop anything, but I want to build it carefully and as much insight that we can gain from our 40-odd years of successful experience. We've never had a failure at this industry. We've never had a real bump. We don't do layoffs. Okay.

componenttext: I'm directing this to Lisa and Ian, but it's also for you, Steve, and Steve, I realize that in your prepared remarks, you said that you can't address this intelligently given the uncertainty, but I really do want to hear how you're all thinking about the deceleration in VIP, GGR and premium mass as you try to run your business and budget for the future. I mean, certainly you must have your own forecast and assumption for when this deceleration slows, even bottoms out. I get this question all the time from investors. I know you get this question, but considering you have your finger on the pulse of this market a lot more than I do, I really do what your thoughts.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Felicia, I think -- this is Gamal. Basically the opportunity we have in the decline of the VIP business has opened a window for us to attract more of the premium and general mass to the property, which you've seen in the first quarter and actually continu
componenttext: Felicia, I think -- this is Gamal. Basically the opportunity we have in the decline of the VIP business has opened a window for us to attract more of the premium and general mass to the property, which you've seen in the first quarter and actually continues in April. It opened up more room inventory, and it allowed us to invite some of our premium and middle tier of the premium market. And as you saw, the market declined about 27%. Wynn Macau declined only by 6% or 7%. So we're making inroads in that category in that segment of the market. I think that's going to continue. Every time we have an opportunity in the decline of the VIP, we'll open it up for the more aspirational premium and general mass. So I think that's a balance that's going to continue until there is a stabilization on the VIP front. Whether that lasts until the second or third or fourth quarter, we will have the flexibility to fill in the room with mass and premium mass customers. So.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's what we -- the President of China expressed as has the Chief Executive, Fernando Choi, this repetition of the desire for the diversification of the offerings in the city. Wynn Palace is primarily a non-casino attraction. Billions of dollars of the
componenttext: That's what we -- the President of China expressed as has the Chief Executive, Fernando Choi, this repetition of the desire for the diversification of the offerings in the city. Wynn Palace is primarily a non-casino attraction. Billions of dollars of the $4 billion are dedicated to non-casino attractions. It becomes -- in a few months when we've filled the lake and turned on the fountains and the gondolas start to flow, it will be the photo op in China just as Bellagio was. It'll be the photo op in China. If that isn't diversification than I need a new lesson in the use of language, but we have followed the guidelines of the government religiously and diversified the offerings that we have. And in private conversations with the government, I raised the question of further diversification, and I'm awaiting their response. The government is tentative at best in responding to us. I think that's a reflection of a little bit of their own uncertainty under the circumstances. I repeat again. The tentativeness of the government is a reflection of their own uncertainty, I believe, in many respects as far as predicting where to go tomorrow or in the near future. There's a new boss in China, Xi Jinping, and his agenda is something that everybody is adjusting to. He's a very dynamic man. He enjoys enormous popularity among the people of China. And in, China, the people matter, and so everybody's waiting and watching.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, do you think that there's a risk as the new properties open this year if they don't grow the market? We talked about social harmony a few questions ago. Do you think that there's a risk of the new properties that open don't grow the market the prop
componenttext: Steve, do you think that there's a risk as the new properties open this year if they don't grow the market? We talked about social harmony a few questions ago. Do you think that there's a risk of the new properties that open don't grow the market the properties that are slated to open in 2016 could get delayed?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know the answer to that question. I don't know how you delay Wynn Palace without causing major social disruption in the city. All of these people, their shares, their jobs, their future, these are Macau people are sitting in anticipation of that e
componenttext: I don't know the answer to that question. I don't know how you delay Wynn Palace without causing major social disruption in the city. All of these people, their shares, their jobs, their future, these are Macau people are sitting in anticipation of that event. There's never been a hotel of this scale in Macau. And Las Vegas, Venetian is -- Wynn Palace is a $4 billion hotel. Now that money was very carefully spent, and you say it slowly 1,700 rooms, $4 billion. This is a fancy piece of business. It is a destination creating -- it creates more of a destination for Macau from people from far away. Remember, growth in the market is a phrase I've used before. Tourism is all about bringing people from over there to over here, and the way you bring people over there to over here is to make sure that what's here is better than what's over there. That simplistic $0.03 as I just said are at the heart of the way we've designed and created based upon 43 years of unparalleled construction. Every project we've ever done has changed the market. We decided that we were going to try and do that again in Macau, and we took our time, as you know, with the Palace, and it represents our very best effort. The city benefits from that in its appeal to the outside world, to bring folks from outside China and from all over the Pacific Rim to Macau just as the other buildings that have been built by Galaxy and by Melco and by Venetian have done that. The growth of that market, its position as a destination in Asia is the most phenomenal modern development in the last 50 years. Why anyone would want to tamper with that or undermine it flies in the face of all of logic that we have been discussing for the past several minutes, but can there be social disruption? For sure. The public and the citizens of Macau have been brought to a higher level of income and a higher level of expectation, and they don't hesitate to express themselves publicly on this subject. The government is now currently awaiting and hoping there won't be any many demonstrations. Just like America, everybody has high hopes, and everybody gets a little spoiled at times, and they want what they want when they want it, and all we do is try and service this expectation as best we can with the help of the government hopefully.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was going to say we think that we haven't just woken up and thought we needed to reconfigure the floor. We've been reconfiguring between mass and VIP now for 9 to 12 months, and we continue to do that, and it's part of our plan going forward. So we're c
componenttext: I was going to say we think that we haven't just woken up and thought we needed to reconfigure the floor. We've been reconfiguring between mass and VIP now for 9 to 12 months, and we continue to do that, and it's part of our plan going forward. So we're constantly reenergizing areas of the casino. The 2 new VIP rooms are under construction for 8 months. It closed down a big section of the casino with a lot of disturbance for 6 months. Now we have a fully operating casino again, but we have future plans as well for the mass casino. We'll continue to recalibrate it and balance between VIP and mass.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Here's a point of interest. When we designed the Palace, it was going to have a spectacularly dramatic front area with the fountains and the gondolas and everything else. And of course, it was going to be serviced by the light rail. It was going to stop r
componenttext: Here's a point of interest. When we designed the Palace, it was going to have a spectacularly dramatic front area with the fountains and the gondolas and everything else. And of course, it was going to be serviced by the light rail. It was going to stop right in the middle of our front area. Well, whether it stops now or later is irrelevant to the fact that we had to answer the question what do we put on the lake? Well, we put major restaurants and then we put VIP rooms. And each of them had -- and our pool and our recreation area, all look over the lake, and the gondolas pass over it look into recreational area of the hotel from about 30 feet off them and about 30 feet out over the water. It's quite dramatic, and there's new music in the gondolas and air-conditioning in the gondolas as people experience this to use a Disney term this. Now, we've decided to put VIP rooms on the lake, and each one of them have balconies. Well you know there's been a crack down on smoking that's very aggressive by the government. There's no misunderstanding their intention or their rational for those things, and our job is to accept those decisions regardless of our own opinions of those decisions. Frankly, the air inside our hotel is better than the air outside of our hotel. But notwithstanding that truth, we were able to take the mass area and some of our regular gaming and put it in these areas on the lake, which means that these tables can take 3 steps and be outside on a smoking balcony. It has unintended consequences, but it tends to mitigate the impact of the smoking ban because all of these areas around the lake have terraces that are open aired and will allow visitors to smoke if that's their pleasure, and so there's a little silver lining to the smoking cloud. We have an advantage that our competitors don't enjoy in regard to that fact. Just a little piece of business that's interesting about it as you reallocate space. Anybody else want to step up?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Well, the light-rail system is a question mark according to the Secretary and his testimony before the. Having covered that, we can turn now to the bridge. headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: The latest estimate on the bridge, Steve, there are some media reports that's not going to be done until 2020. We have someone high in government, and he said that's not correct that it should be done by the end of '17. So that's the latest information, but that's a moving target for these people.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's different responsibilities, Steve, with different governments. The Macau side may very well be ready, but on the Hong Kong side, you have some big reclaimed land infrastructure to take care of. So we're depending on 3 parties, Mainland China, Maca
componenttext: There's different responsibilities, Steve, with different governments. The Macau side may very well be ready, but on the Hong Kong side, you have some big reclaimed land infrastructure to take care of. So we're depending on 3 parties, Mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong to get the bridge finished. So the number as Gamal -- the year as Gamal said is around 2020. That's pretty much the latest that we've heard.

And as Steve said, hopefully we'll meet breaking ground sometimes by the end of the year in Everett. So we're making a lot of progress on that front.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Build it in '16 and '17, and hopefully, get it open at the end of '17 or close to it. We had to make some changes in plans to accommodate as we've learned this year, the weather, and so we've revisited our project to make sure we had adequate snowmelt and
componenttext: Build it in '16 and '17, and hopefully, get it open at the end of '17 or close to it. We had to make some changes in plans to accommodate as we've learned this year, the weather, and so we've revisited our project to make sure we had adequate snowmelt and the proper disposition of snow when it accumulates so as not interfere with business. And again remember you can't just push the snow into the Mystic River. That's against the law. You have to store the water. You have to deal with the snow when it melts, and we've accommodated all of those things. It's a new challenge for us so it's very interesting to do. I spent several months with my colleague with whom I designed these hotels, and we've made changes to ensure that even if there's a blizzard, you'll be able to turn off Alford Street and be on dry pavement as you go to our port shares or our garage. I'm very high on the Boston project and see no reason to say anything else. But timing will depend upon Massachusetts' substantial and formidable regulatory hurdles. Here's a project between $1.5 billion to $2 billion that has $300-odd million. Matt, why don't you put a fine point to this? Hear this now. This is very interesting. In order to build something that is the largest employer, private employer in the state of Massachusetts that will contribute more jobs and more revenue to the state than anything they've seen in decades, how much money have we spent that is not going into the project itself, Matt, just to get into the position to build?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to get into the position to build? So we've spent $200 million to date on the project, and we do not plan on breaking ground until the end of the year. I think we probably have another $100 million to go this year, Steve, with remediation and various
componenttext: Just to get into the position to build? So we've spent $200 million to date on the project, and we do not plan on breaking ground until the end of the year. I think we probably have another $100 million to go this year, Steve, with remediation and various fees that Massachusetts Gaming Commissions. I think we'll spend $300 million to break that ground.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fixing streets in the related -- in the neighboring communities, working on traffic resolution, environmental and other things, the hurdle is substantial, and that's what it takes to build a grand hotel in Massachusetts. Welcome to the regulated business
componenttext: Fixing streets in the related -- in the neighboring communities, working on traffic resolution, environmental and other things, the hurdle is substantial, and that's what it takes to build a grand hotel in Massachusetts. Welcome to the regulated business in America. The bureaucratic challenges are endless, and this doesn't just apply to our industry. It applies to all businesses. And at one point, investors and citizens can take note of this as they clamor for more jobs, as they clamor for more government support, think of the jumps that private enterprise has to make in order to get the job done. It's daunting. You can quit, retire or you can keep up the effort in the hopes that these energies are rewarded at the end of the day by patronage. It requires a bit, but I guess we're true believers around here. So off we go onward and upward, Excelsior. How satisfying is that to the group on this call? You've got to have a sense of humor about this stuff, ladies and gentlemen. I imagine Sheldon's listening, and he's chuckling at this point.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for holding and welcome to the First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Steve Cootey, Chief Financial Officer, Wynn Resorts. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for holding and welcome to the First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Steve Cootey, Chief Financial Officer, Wynn Resorts. Please go ahead.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Joining the call on behalf of the company today are Steve Wynn, Matt Maddox, John Strzemp, Kim Sinatra, Maurice Wooden, myself here in Las Vegas; Gamal Aziz, Linda Chen, Ian Coughlan, Frederic Luvisutto, Robert Gansmo and Fr
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Joining the call on behalf of the company today are Steve Wynn, Matt Maddox, John Strzemp, Kim Sinatra, Maurice Wooden, myself here in Las Vegas; Gamal Aziz, Linda Chen, Ian Coughlan, Frederic Luvisutto, Robert Gansmo and Frank Cassella dialing in from Wynn Macau.
Before we get started, I just want to remind everyone that we will be making forward-looking statements under the safe harbor federal securities law, and those statements may or may not come true.
And with that, I'm going to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Wynn.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the numbers in the first quarter are out. I think the trends in Macau were beginning to be very visible in the fourth quarter, but our hopes for an improvement in the Chinese New Year turned out to be incorrect and the repositioning of the market an
componenttext:
Well, the numbers in the first quarter are out. I think the trends in Macau were beginning to be very visible in the fourth quarter, but our hopes for an improvement in the Chinese New Year turned out to be incorrect and the repositioning of the market and the degradation of the volumes in VIP have continued even into April.
I'm going to -- most of my remarks now are going to include what we've seen in the first 4 months, not just the first 3 months because the trends that were clear in January, February and March have continued into April. And as we look at the whole year in Las Vegas and Macau, certain simple truths emerge. It is no secret that there's been a change in Mainland China in attitudes towards a number of things that have impacted Macau. That has not -- nothing has changed since this all began last October, and the depression of the VIP market continues. Business is off [ph] 44%, 45% or something like that.
It is impossible for us to predict how long that will last. We're not in a position to answer those kinds of questions intelligently. We're only in a position to react intelligently to what we see. We run this company and we have at all times with a few simple guidelines and principles.
Number one, we want to maximize shareholder value, for the people that actually own the company. We want to always be able to honor our debts and never have to ask for reconsideration. In order to do that, we pay careful attention to the capital structure of the company.
At the core of the whole discussion is what is the franchise of a business like Wynn Resorts or even the others in the hospitality business, and it's simply guest experience. Guest experience is what creates a better tomorrow and allows us to continue in business, eventually raise our prices to offset the rising cost of business. People, when they have a good experience, tell their friends, and they come back again and again.
Guest experience is the beginning, the middle and the end of the story. If you accept that as a truth then, of course, guest experience is determined by our employees, the people that actually touch our guests and create that experience. So our attention goes from our balance sheet and our financial condition to maintain flexibility, but also it goes immediately to keeping our workforce stabilized, happy and proud to be here. That's the core of our business plan. That's the core of our understanding, and every major decision in this company is determined by those principles alone: protect the employee attitudes and morale because they impact and they really create the guest experience.
In order to do that, again, our financial condition has to remain flexible, strong and secure. In the 40-odd years I've been in the business, we've never altered a debt or any of that sort of thing and we don't ever intend to do it.
So as we look backwards for the fourth quarter and especially during the last 4 months and understand what's happening both in Las Vegas because of the Asian impact of baccarat, and we look back and then we extrapolate and try and predict the future or at least understand what most likely will be the future, it is foolhardy and immature and unsophisticated to issue dividends on borrowed money. We only distribute money that's free cash flow based upon our earnings trail.
Therefore, today we lowered the dividend as we have raised it in the past. Based upon financial results, we are lowering it today to $0.50 a quarter, and I might add that I and my Board of Directors would not hesitate to adjust the dividend down or up based upon performance without a second thought and without any apology.
Dividends are nothing, and we don't say that because we have a business that we now have a $0.50 dividends forever. That's baloney. Any company that does that is irresponsible. We distribute the money that we make after we make provisions for capital expenditures and all of our other obligations to creditors and to our employees, and then we distribute aggressively whatever is free and easy to distribute after that.
Now I'm speaking on this call as the largest single recipient of such distributions. There's a few institutions that, if you take T. Rowe Price own more shares collectively at least for the moment, but they're in individual pockets. When there's a dividend check in this company, the largest one goes to me. And so I say again unapologetically, as a shareholder and as Chairman of the Board, we believe that you distribute the money that's free and clear cash flow after you've met all other obligations and the Board of Directors should consider that principle every time they meet each quarter as we did this time. And I hope that those comments summarize not only our current attitude but will allow anybody to predict our future behavior in Wynn Resorts with regard to distributions.
We have 2 projects that are aggressive and ambitious. One of them is a $4 billion Wynn Palace in Macau, which even though we struggled with adjusting our work schedule on construction to the permissions we've been given for workers on construction by the government, we believe we're going to be open at the end of the first quarter next year in March. And Wynn Palace will quite simply be the most extravagant and beautiful hotel in the world, 1,700 rooms, and I don't think there's ever been anything quite like what we're going to show off next year. It took us 2 years to plan it. It's taken 4 years to build it. Big, long project conceived by people with experience and I think will be a powerful addition to the Macau market, whatever size that Macau market may be at the moment. We do not know how many tables we're going to have. That's a very difficult uncertainty to adjust to but nevertheless, it is the uncertainty of the moment as to what the government will do.
When we started the project, we had an understanding that the table levels would -- that we would need approximately the same amount of tables as we had at The Peninsula Hotel and nobody objected. But then subsequent to our beginning, the government made an announcement to institute a cap of certain percentage of table increases a year. They've said that the allocation of that percentage of extra tables is a decision that they will make based upon a number of factors, and they will weigh such factors as diversification non-casino versus casino.
The Wynn Palace is the most extravagant exercise in non-casino attractions in Macau. We've taken entertainment to every restaurant. We've taken massive public entertainment to the front and dedicated a huge portion of our real estate to public entertainment for tens of millions of dollars, approximately $100 million when we're done, with just the front lake.
So it's going to be the big photo op for Macau, and it will show up next year hopefully with enough tables to allow it to prosper. We'll begin construction this fall in Boston. We've made most of the financial arrangements to finance those projects. Macau was completely financed. Boston is almost completely financed at very favorable rates with a debt that is nonrecourse to the parent.
And so the company at the moment is on strong financial footing. I don't know whether with this change in EBITDA whether S&P and Moody's will continue our bond rating as favorably as they have in the past, but the fundamental health of the company is perfect and without question and my intention is to keep it that way without any qualification to that statement.
Now we'll take questions, and all of the executives in China and Las Vegas are here to get into the detail of these stories. I just wanted to provide the overview. With that, we'll take questions.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Carlo Santarelli of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Carlo Santarelli of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've long been a proponent of having a capital structure that match the operating environment, so I don't think this necessarily would come as a total surprise. But as you contemplated the dividend and you thought about some of the CapEx expenditures th
componenttext: You've long been a proponent of having a capital structure that match the operating environment, so I don't think this necessarily would come as a total surprise. But as you contemplated the dividend and you thought about some of the CapEx expenditures that were coming over the next few years, what kind of drove you to make this decision today? And does it say anything about your view on the outlook for Macau over the next 18 to 24 months other than just what we've already seen and that it remains very murky?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Carlo, it's Matt Maddox. When we were reviewing this, Steve put it perfectly that we don't plan on dividend-ing out our own money. And so if you look at our payout ratio based on our adjusted earnings per share, what we're looking at right now is si
componenttext: Sure. Carlo, it's Matt Maddox. When we were reviewing this, Steve put it perfectly that we don't plan on dividend-ing out our own money. And so if you look at our payout ratio based on our adjusted earnings per share, what we're looking at right now is similar to what we did last year. So that's really the way we're looking at the capital structure, and there's so much uncertainty right now in Las Vegas, in Macau and with our project coming on next year that we're just not going to be dividend-ing borrowed money.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then if I could, just one follow up on Macau guys. Was there any differential or any meaningful differential between your direct and VIP on the hold side, or what we're seeing maybe a little bit of the cost creep from some of the fixed exp
componenttext: Understood. And then if I could, just one follow up on Macau guys. Was there any differential or any meaningful differential between your direct and VIP on the hold side, or what we're seeing maybe a little bit of the cost creep from some of the fixed expenses in the business?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that there was really no impact from a hold standpoint on margins and clearly, there's a little bit of cost creep. If you look at the fourth quarter of '14 to the first quarter this year, you can see that, and operating expenses today are up a
componenttext: I would say that there was really no impact from a hold standpoint on margins and clearly, there's a little bit of cost creep. If you look at the fourth quarter of '14 to the first quarter this year, you can see that, and operating expenses today are up around 7%.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our new junket rooms did well. But the other junket operators that weren't quite as powerful is -- I wouldn't say they scavenge the other ones, but the new junket rooms are in the hands of very well-financed operators. So the rooms were very well received
componenttext: Our new junket rooms did well. But the other junket operators that weren't quite as powerful is -- I wouldn't say they scavenge the other ones, but the new junket rooms are in the hands of very well-financed operators. So the rooms were very well received, and they've been lively and they've been busy.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions on occupancy. So in Macau, your occupancy held in relatively well. Some of your peers you saw sizable drops. Can you just talk about your expectations of occupancy trends in Macau going forward, especially after we all saw March visitation
componenttext: So 2 questions on occupancy. So in Macau, your occupancy held in relatively well. Some of your peers you saw sizable drops. Can you just talk about your expectations of occupancy trends in Macau going forward, especially after we all saw March visitation dropping down significantly? And then just second part of the question is just on Vegas, we saw a decline in occupancy. Was that a function of just the CON/AGG comp or something else?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, CON/AGG. Go ahead, Matt.
componenttext: Yes, CON/AGG. Go ahead, Matt.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Yes, Ian, you want to take the Macau call? And Maurice, you can add some color on Las Vegas?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a slightly different eco climate on The Peninsula. We also have a smaller inventory of rooms than the big operators in Cotai. So with 1,000 keys, we also had a shift of rooms into our premium mass and mass segments. So we have some new reward
componenttext: Yes, we have a slightly different eco climate on The Peninsula. We also have a smaller inventory of rooms than the big operators in Cotai. So with 1,000 keys, we also had a shift of rooms into our premium mass and mass segments. So we have some new reward programs where we're getting approximately 100 rooms a day more to our premium mass and mass areas, where we've been able to grow a midsection of our mass business very nicely despite the downturn in business. So we've utilized the inventory where the business is. So we've kept our occupancy virtually the same as last year.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in Las Vegas, the first quarter, we saw a lot of compression with convention business in the month of January where there was a lot of opportunity. We just didn't have all the room inventory...
componenttext: So in Las Vegas, the first quarter, we saw a lot of compression with convention business in the month of January where there was a lot of opportunity. We just didn't have all the room inventory...

componenttext: So where you have a lot of business that really was interested at being in Las Vegas during that month as opposed to the previous year where we're spread out throughout February and March as well. And of course, you had mentioned March as far as CON/AGG and CONEX (sic) [CONEXPO] and that was a big impact for us from a revenue perspective as well as room night perspective.

componenttext: How do you see -- we might as well get into this. How do you see May and June and the summer at this point for Las Vegas?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, for April and May, we have a strong base and stable base of convention as well as leisure mix. Summer's going to be interesting. We're starting to see summer trends not pick up the same way they did in previous year. So we're paying very close atten
componenttext: Well, for April and May, we have a strong base and stable base of convention as well as leisure mix. Summer's going to be interesting. We're starting to see summer trends not pick up the same way they did in previous year. So we're paying very close attention to the market and what we're getting as indicators as far as the summer business, but it does not seem as strong at this point as it was last year.

componenttext: And business in April -- compare business in April compared to business in March.

componenttext: So April's business is much better than March, a lot more stable, equal -- the base is more equalized with respect to the different segments that are filling our rooms here, and so we had a better convention base...

componenttext: But in terms of the whole operation in Las Vegas, the EBITDA decline that we've been seeing continues?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I -- if you were to ask me, since we're making forward-looking statements, what will the second quarter look like in Las Vegas? Weak. Do you hear me? Weak. So I'm trying to lower expectations here. This notion of a big recovery is a complete dream. I don'
componenttext: I -- if you were to ask me, since we're making forward-looking statements, what will the second quarter look like in Las Vegas? Weak. Do you hear me? Weak. So I'm trying to lower expectations here. This notion of a big recovery is a complete dream. I don't think Las Vegas is experiencing a great recovery. I think it's still very patchy, and I think that's probably -- our non-casino revenue in the first quarter was flat. I'd be thrilled if it was flat in the second quarter. Would you, Maurice?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would be.
componenttext: I would be.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now did you hear that? Here's 2 of us saying we'd be thrilled if non-casino revenue was flat on the second quarter as it was in the first. My guess is that that's going to be a struggle.
componenttext: Yes. Now did you hear that? Here's 2 of us saying we'd be thrilled if non-casino revenue was flat on the second quarter as it was in the first. My guess is that that's going to be a struggle.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what do you think is driving it? I mean, as you think about this summer, is that the strengthening U.S. dollar? Is it something else? And then just I'm going to sneak in one more question. Just when you talked about Cotai Palace opening up or being rea
componenttext: So what do you think is driving it? I mean, as you think about this summer, is that the strengthening U.S. dollar? Is it something else? And then just I'm going to sneak in one more question. Just when you talked about Cotai Palace opening up or being ready to open up in March of next year, can you just give us an update on just the labor allocation? I think there was some issue about -- with that last quarter, then I'm done.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, on our labor allocation, we got less than we asked for than we appealed, and they gave us some more. Then we made another application, and they gave us less than we asked for and we appealed that. I'm not sure how exactly the process works in the ca
componenttext: Well, on our labor allocation, we got less than we asked for than we appealed, and they gave us some more. Then we made another application, and they gave us less than we asked for and we appealed that. I'm not sure how exactly the process works in the calculations that are done at the Labor Department in Macau. These jobs, after all, are people from Mainland China just on the other side of the fence. But there's pressure locally. I guess it's sort of the locals don't want the streets too crowded or something, and they put pressure on the local government officials and they respond -- they're very sensitive to local pressure. So it leaves us in a bit of quandary. We never know quite what to expect these days and uncertainty -- for our employees, we're beginning to notice that our -- we have the lowest -- let me just start over on this. In that town where there's a 25% to 30% turnover rate, our company stands alone with a current rate of 8%. All of last year was 11%. We have -- our employees are very sticky. They like us. They stay with us. That's a big advantage when you're building a new property. However, every one of our employees in Macau is a shareholder of Wynn Macau, and they're counting on the accumulated dividends, the value of those shares as their basic savings. The current situation in Macau is threatening them and unfortunately, I'm not in a position to protect them from the exposures attendant [ph] to the changes that have been brought about in the marketplace. We try and deal with that as we build the new place. But there's no question that uncertainty is the plaguing word of the day in Macau. And hopefully, our government in Macau will calm that down and put some certainty back into the picture, and that will be very important to the employees who are basically Macau citizens, but they're beginning to feel these rumbles and I fear that, that may erupt into protests against the government if it isn't settled soon.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And sorry, just following up from my first question. What do you think is driving the weakness during the summer in Las Vegas? Is that the stronger U.S. dollar? Is that fewer play out of China? And then, again, I'm done after that.
componenttext: And sorry, just following up from my first question. What do you think is driving the weakness during the summer in Las Vegas? Is that the stronger U.S. dollar? Is that fewer play out of China? And then, again, I'm done after that.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Both of the 2 things that you just mentioned are at play. And secondly or thirdly, the recovery in America is a jobless recovery in real terms and inflation in America in real terms is an enormous number. So I think that the general economic recovery in t
componenttext: Both of the 2 things that you just mentioned are at play. And secondly or thirdly, the recovery in America is a jobless recovery in real terms and inflation in America in real terms is an enormous number. So I think that the general economic recovery in the United States has been grossly overstated, and we're an echo of that here in Las Vegas as one of America's main destination resort cities. And all of you get to hear these kinds of comments from other public companies that are engaged in this business, and I think the picture's beginning to emerge.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Greff of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Greff of JPMorgan.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe this is a difficult question to answer, Steve, and I think you touched on it in a couple of the answers here. But do you think the Macau government cares if the new projects that are opening in Cotai over the next few years, if those new projects ca
componenttext: Maybe this is a difficult question to answer, Steve, and I think you touched on it in a couple of the answers here. But do you think the Macau government cares if the new projects that are opening in Cotai over the next few years, if those new projects cannibalize the existing base of casino hotels, particularly if that generates disruptions to social harmony locally in Macau? How do those topics of conversation, how do they go when you potentially bring that up as a topic of conversation with the government there?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: What a great question, and first of all, it will impact social harmony. But the government officials are balancing, I think at this point, a lot of issues that have emanated from Beijing and also emanates from their own population. How they walk that tigh
componenttext: What a great question, and first of all, it will impact social harmony. But the government officials are balancing, I think at this point, a lot of issues that have emanated from Beijing and also emanates from their own population. How they walk that tight rope and what their decisions are, are at the moment, unpredictable to us because we can't sit in their -- we can't stand in their shoes. We don't really know how much pressure they feel in different areas. We hear their public statements and we certainly enjoy private conversations with them, but they tend to be very formal. They're never critical of anything directly. When they want something, they make requests. It's a very civilized process, but there's no question that the atmosphere there has changed and become cloudier in terms of predictability and consistency. It's definitely become cloudy. They had a press conference. One of the new ministers, as part of this government, made a statement in front of legislature that the light-rail system, which has been underdevelopment for 5 years that I'm aware of or 6 years, that they don't have any idea exactly when it'll be finished or what it's going to cost. I'm sure that was a painful thing for the man to say exact words. You cannot excuse the unexcusable. I'm here just to apologize. Well, if that's going on at the highest levels of the government in Macau, you can imagine how -- what happens as it filters down to those of us who are part of the resort industry. So I don't know if I'm being very helpful in passing on my impressions, but I'm doing the best I can.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I have a quick question following up on your rather crystal clear comments on the Las Vegas Strip. If you were to look at the non-Chinese resort baccarat player, is that segment on the Las Vegas Strip relatively healthier or in good shape?
componenttext: Great. And then I have a quick question following up on your rather crystal clear comments on the Las Vegas Strip. If you were to look at the non-Chinese resort baccarat player, is that segment on the Las Vegas Strip relatively healthier or in good shape?

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say it's just not necessarily healthier. I would, again, look at the same trends that we have with respect to Far East market. I think that they are paying close attention to traveling over here and whether they should or whether they shouldn't. S
componenttext: I would say it's just not necessarily healthier. I would, again, look at the same trends that we have with respect to Far East market. I think that they are paying close attention to traveling over here and whether they should or whether they shouldn't. So if that's measurable, it's a little different than watching our high-end play.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're going to have -- or we're having this call today on the eve of the upcoming Pacquiao fight and Mayweather fight and this, in my 40-odd years in this town, this is a one-off. I have never seen madness and demand of this sort. This fight is probably g
componenttext: We're going to have -- or we're having this call today on the eve of the upcoming Pacquiao fight and Mayweather fight and this, in my 40-odd years in this town, this is a one-off. I have never seen madness and demand of this sort. This fight is probably going to break all records for pay-per-view. It certainly is breaking all records in what they're getting for tickets. We've never charged more than $1,500 for a ringside seat in a fight and they're going for $10,000 and $7,500 for the medium range and then $5,000 for the ones in the upper tier, an outrageous amount of money. Mayweather and Pacquiao are going to not only have to have a fight, but they're probably going to have to do a chorus line or something to justify the cost of this. But our room rates are at $1,300, $1,400, $1,500 for typical rooms and you can't get a room in this town. I've never seen anything like it even when Hagler fought Leonard, when Ali -- nothing like this. And there's a lot of baccarat business coming to town this weekend, a ton of it. So we're going to have one of these New Year's Eve, Chinese New Year puffs, but I'm trying to give an overview here of what's really going on in terms of the tempo of the city here and in Macau. And I think we ought to keep our eye on the long view as opposed to the short view.

componenttext: Just to circle back to the dividend philosophy for a quick second. And I was wondering, is that something that we should look to as sort of a guidepost for this? And how often should we think that the dividend will be reevaluated? Is this a quarterly thing? Or is it going to be kind of this is what you think you need to get through Cotai from here?

componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to answer. It's Steve. It is quarterly reviewed. We said $0.50 a share because we thought that was a relatively stable number, a couple hundred million dollars. If we do $1 billion in EBITDA or something like that, we'd probably have $400
componenttext: Well, I'm going to answer. It's Steve. It is quarterly reviewed. We said $0.50 a share because we thought that was a relatively stable number, a couple hundred million dollars. If we do $1 billion in EBITDA or something like that, we'd probably have $400 million in free cash flow, right, Matt?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so we said, well, we could safely say half of that. We could have said $3 instead of $2 a year, but I decided that until we get a clearer picture of this, I was going to try to avoid another reduction if I could. But I want to make it clear, Mr. Kelle
componenttext: And so we said, well, we could safely say half of that. We could have said $3 instead of $2 a year, but I decided that until we get a clearer picture of this, I was going to try to avoid another reduction if I could. But I want to make it clear, Mr. Kelley. I wouldn't think twice if there was another big change in changing it every quarter, up or down. Make no mistake about it. We do not feel it is an appropriate, prudent management to make promises about distribution in a business that fluctuates. Now that may be bad news to some investors who would prefer to know that it just comes off like a clockwork, but this is not that kind of a company, and it's never really going to be that kind of a company. We'll get bigger. I think we'll do fine with Cotai as a percentage of return on its investment. I think we'll do great in Boston as a percentage of return on its investment. And therefore, the company will grow and the available cash flow will increase hopefully and so will our dividend because we're a distribution company. But at the moment, I mean, one of the benefits of the fact that we are a distribution company is that we distributed billions of dollars to our shareholders. That's good news, but it's not an inherent promise of a fixed amount of money. It's only an inherent promise of our approach to the problem. Hear me on this. There'll be no change in that attitude while I'm sitting in my chair.

headline: Wynn Resorts Ltd., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. I think that's crystal clear. And then I guess a second question, and this is certainly changing topics a little bit, was I noticed in the release that when you look at the mix in the mass business and what you saw during the quarter, look at the
componenttext: Got it. I think that's crystal clear. And then I guess a second question, and this is certainly changing topics a little bit, was I noticed in the release that when you look at the mix in the mass business and what you saw during the quarter, look at the whole ratio, it was up. It's always been hard to read those numbers particularly in recent times. But my question is did you guys see more of a shift to premium mass in the quarter? Or was it pretty balanced between what you saw in sort of the more grind mass and the higher end part of mass? Just kind of curious to what you guys saw throughout the quarter.
